>>179158254
When I was a Park Ranger at a park that touched the coast AND private properties we actually had to go code 3 to these calls ASAP because most people don't realize that seals will flat out bite off your face if you aggravate them. It's also illegal to molest one, so if there's a seal in your pool (rare but it happens) then there's just a seal in your pool. Best I could do was put up a sign that stated not to bother the marine mammal. Literally an arrestable offense to interfere with one, and a big time felony if you kill one.

Fun fact: the only time you're justified in killing a seal is if it jumps onto your boat while you're in the ocean so you can safely throw it off your boat, because as you can see in OP's video, whales will knock over your boat just to get to their dinner.

Pic related, it's a cool salamander I rescued from some dude that collected wild animals.

For the main plot of the movie there are some essential things like the raid on his village, the slavery thing, him fighting some thulsa doom people etc. Then there's stuff that doesn't feel essential like the robbing of the tower or the fucking the witch. Conan is a lot like a spaghetti western where there's a main narrative and some side things that at times feel random. It's like the spaghetti western of fantasy basically.

They robbed the tower to:

1. Introduce Valeria and gives us an idea of her character

>>179155322
Have you ever read the books? Or even the pulp magazine comics? Anything beyond the films?

Conan is not the best at anything. He's a product of a harsh and unforgiving upbringing and his greatest strength is that he manages to still have compassion in spite of it. He fucks whores, kills men, regularly gets himself tricked or cheated and usually have to rely on his gut feelings and mistrust to keep him safe.
While he's a fearsome combatant he can and has been bested many times. He usually gets into terrible situations that he only narrowly escapes at the cost of friends and lovers, like walking into a storm because he wanted to see if he could fuck Ymir's daughter and ends up having to fight frost giants. Or being enslaved by Hyperboreans and being responsible for the death of hundreds of slaves in a failed revolt.

He's middling in many ways, and at the same time he is the protagonist. Not sure what you expected but you evidently never understood the character.

I was going to post Big O, but instead I'll post pic related. They put a lot of effort into the stop motion for this film. A lot of little details that no one would notice on a first watch. It already gets a lot of praise for its story and music, perhaps even an overrated aspect of the movie, but the animation is far and away some of the best in the craft.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>179151070
i know it kinda got spammed when it came out but this one is legitimately good. its well told, concise, and has an actual ending and isnt some "stay tuned" series that drags on forever. the story it tells has been told before but instead of trying to reinvent the wheel it tells it well.

the animation is stylish with some nice flourishes on character design and a neat motion effect during the slow motion parts, the characters are all memorable and it doesnt feel like there was a single unnecessary cast member, they all get utilized well.

the sound track is well produced and enhances the show instead of just being background noise

it was really surprising to see an anime/cartoon of this quality come out in this day and age, it reminds me more of the type of stuff that was coming out in the 90s

>show cut penny because ???
Sweets dabbed at Yezzan’s fevered face with a damp cloth. “Yezzan must live. Or we all die with him. The pale mare does not carry off every rider. The master will recover.”
That was a bald-faced lie. It would be a wonder if Yezzan lived another day. The lord of suet was already dying from whatever hideous disease he had brought back from Sothoryos, it seemed to Tyrion. This would just hasten his end. A mercy, really. But not the sort the dwarf craved for himself. “The healer said he needs fresh water. We will see to that.”
“That is good of you.” Sweets sounded numb. It was more than just fear of having her throat cut; alone amongst Yezzan’s treasures, she actually seemed fond of their immense master.
“Penny, come with me.” Tyrion opened the tent flap and ushered her out into the heat of a Meereenese morning. The air was muggy and oppressive, yet still a welcome relief from the miasma of sweat, shit, and sickness that filled the inside of Yezzan’s palatial pavilion.
“Water will help the master,” Penny said. “That’s what the healer said, it must be so. Sweet fresh water.”
“Sweet fresh water didn’t help Nurse.” Poor old Nurse. Yezzan’s soldiers had tossed him onto the corpse wagon last night at dusk, another victim of the pale mare. When men are dying every hour, no one looks too hard at one more dead man, especially one as well despised as Nurse. Yezzan’s other slaves had refused to go near the overseer once the cramps began, so it was left to Tyrion to keep him warm and bring him drinks. Watered wine and lemonsweet and some nice hot dogtail soup, with slivers of mushroom in the broth. Drink it down, Nursey, that shitwater squirting from your arse needs to be replaced. The last word Nurse ever said was, “No.” The last words he ever heard were, “A Lannister always pays his debts.”
Tyrion had kept the truth of that from Penny, but she needed to understand how things stood with their master.

>>179147286
The entire premise is that the universe of ReBoot exists within a computer whether the computers user is interacting with it at all or not. Bob is a Guardian of the universe within, assumes the avatars for the computer games that get input by the user. He's accompanied by friends who help him in this endeavour, Enzo and his sister Dot Matrix, as they work to keep the computer system of Mainframe safe from the viruses known as Megabyte and Hexadecimal. The setting is in the inner world of a computer system known by its inhabitants as Mainframe. It was deliberately chosen due to technological constraints at the time, as the fictional computer world allowed for blocky looking models and mechanical animation. One recurring plot thread: when the User loads a game, an electrical violet cube lowers onto part of the city. Anyone trapped inside becomes NPCs and have the chance to stop the User. If the User wins, the area is destroyed and the residents reduced to leech like creatures called Nulls.

The series goes further from this premise as it goes on, of course. Its a very original show tiliizing the best computer animation had to offer at the time and this improves as the show goes on. Its a definite footnote in computer animation history.

Reboot only showed seasons 1 and 2 on US TV initially, ABC Kids specifically. It was pulled shortly after but Season 3 was shown in Canada/UK in 1997.

However in 1999 it was picked up dirt cheap by Toonami and season 3 finally aired on US TV. It became so popular on Toonami that a quasi-4th season covering the Daemon arc was then developed and aired in 2001.

If you saw Reboot season 3 or any season after 1995 in the US, it was on Toonami

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
> be Knighted by the King or other nobleman
> serve him for an agreed number of days every year
> be given a manor; thats up to a few thousand acres to your name depending on how valuable each acre is
> you call your manor a "farm". Its a village with farmland, woodland, and wetland around it
> have a country house at your manor and rent a townhouse at the city or town where the King's castle is at
> lease your lands to peasants. They pay you rent for the land (ground rent) every year of an agreed amount
> lease the office of bailiff to someone (family member?) to do duties like to collect rents and oversee workers hired to do tasks for you such as builders and gardeners
> build a mill to lease to a miller
> build an oven to lease to a baker
> build a forge to lease to a blacksmith
> build fruit press to lease to a tavern keeper
> (maybe) build beehive to raise bees for honey and candlewax
> grow orchard and vineyard to sell
> have a flock of sheep or herd of cattle or herd of swine or goat; hire herdsmen to take care of
> build weir for fishing
> build parish church for a friar
> lease land to craftmen to open up shops in your farm such as:
> carpenter for woodwork
> potter for earthenware
> tanner for leatherware
> weaver for cloth
Your farm/manor/village (whatever you may call it though farm was often used because you farm money from it to pay for your lifestyle and service to your King or other lord) grows bigger over the years if prosperous
> the value of your land grows so you demand more coin/crops in rent every instance you lease land
> most farms had about a hundred people living in them, with a few having either fewer or much more
> everytime you return to your country house from your service, you must hear pleas from your tenants and settle disputes between them, with a jury of their peers helping to decide who is wrong and who owes what in fines
> your bailiff collects those fines ofcourse
I can go on

>>179158037
What most people dont understand is that it was never really about the joke, but the delivery. They could have easily given the shop any funny name and everyone would have just kept watching and never paid it any mind. They could have. They didnt. Someone, maybe multiple writers, decided that this shop was different. You can imagine the room. Someone comes out with a silly, somewhat witty name, and everyone agrees. A light switches on in someones head. Its so simple, so elegant, but nobody had thought of it until then. A joke that the kids wouldnt understand but the adults would love. A timeless pun, leaving the joke to be resolved in the mind of the viewer, we were lead to the joke instead of having it forced upon us. I believe this is why, to this very day and all over the globe, youll hear sniggles and giggles at the first word of the joke. Sneed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>179154541

A couple of factors

1. Divers have a finite amount of time they can be underwater by virtue of the fact they require oxygen tanks. If you run out of O2 and you aren't able to surface, you're as good as dead.

2. Large ships by their very nature are made up of very narrow spaces that are extremely easy to become lost in, even if you were a member of the crew.

3. The ease of which you can get lost in the interior of a ship is further compounded by the lack of light.

4. Shipwrecks, even ones where the vessel appears to have sunk mostly intact from the exterior, often violently deform the interior. Entire decks can be reduced to an unrecognizable mass of twisted steel. Debris renders corridors impassable. Entire sections of the hulk might have been crushed by the impact on the sea floor. It'd be like trying to navigate through a half-demolished building.

5. Diving often requires bulky equipment (such as oxygen tanks) and this can easily become snagged in the crammed interior of a wreck. You might well know where you are and still wind up stuck.

6. Shipwrecks close too shore have the added risks of fishing nets that were caught on the wreck and torn off their trawlers and silt being kicked up when disturbed.

tl;dr I love ships and boats, but diving anything other than a wrecked tugboat is definitely something I would be hesitant to do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>179149843
>super thick bones
Nobody said anything about super thick bones. Replicants just need to be in the physical range of best humans or slightly above that to perform as well as they do in the movie. In fact, they necessarily have to be as close to humans as possible and adding any mutations differentiating them from humans is a hard task for bioengineering reasons, which is why changing the smell of their farts would be at the bottom of the priorities list. I mean, it's basic biology/genetics - the more you fiddle with the organism, the less stable the result will be and >99% of changes would always result in a catastrophic failure.
>Pretty sure a simple device to see if the person has super thick bones can be cobbled together or something
If by 'simple device' you mean a whole ass x-ray machine, then yeah, you could do it, Okay, let's say you can do that and you can somehow reliably measure whether one bone is 10% denser than other (which, by the way, I doubt you could do even on the modern x-rays I've been posting in this thread). Why would you use it over a Voight-Kampff test? Cause you want to give people cancer? It's not going to be particularly faster - x-rays take time as well, people need to undress and stand still and if they twitch you have to redo it and risk their (and your) health for no particular reason.
>And they scan eyes but their eyes react differently under dim lights for movie so the handheld scanner Harrison pulls out can use a flash
Voight-Kampff test includes looking at pupils, yes. Not sure what you're getting at.
>despite most of them being the off world workforce where nobody would tell
Yeah, I guess they could just break the law and risk getting raped by government if it ever found out. But you know what the funny thing is? They don't need to. All modern technology has planned obsolescence. Doesn't stop Apple from being one of the largest companies in the world.

By the way, let's say they did ignore the law and Roy Batty's group of escapees didn't have a limited lifespan. What does Tyrell do then? Try to hide the truth? What happens when years pass and replicants are still alive and on the run? It's an absolute nightmare scenario for Tyrell, both in terms or PR and legal liability.
If you think about it, it's genuinely impressive how coherent BR universe is. You'd expect it to break down if you dig deep enough - after all, the screenwriters are just humans and most science fiction relies on some benefit of the doubt, but I still don't think that another anon managed to point out any serious logical inconsistencies. The majority of confusion, once again, simply stems from the fact that people can't tell bioengineering apart from mechanical engineering, even though it should be a concept evident to any modern educated adult.

Enjoyable Western. John C. Reilly and Joaquin had good chemistry as brothers. Jake Gyllenhaal and Riz Ahmed were also good together. The bulk of the movie is more of a chase on horses than a western really, but there's some good stuff in it. It bombed, making 18 million on a 31 million budget.

Sometimes it felt a bit uneven tonally, missing to walk the fine line between comedy and seriousness. And the ending is just weird.

Also Rutger Hauer is in this for five seconds. It was his last movie. I think he must've dropped dead during shooting, lel. Because it makes no sense for him to be in it for five seconds, or maybe it's in there as a joke: to have a big name cameo like that.

Anyway: if you like westerns, it's definitely worth a shot. It's an original take on it. Didn't care much for the soundtrack, so it's good that it was used sparingly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Seen this movie 4 times so far in theaters.

Finally got to see it in 4k HFR today on a 70' screen. Oh man. So good. Barco DP4K-23B projector.

I mean the plot is basically pic related.

And what's more, IRL I'm a commercial scuba diver, and grew up in a native american household culturally. So this freaking movie man, I mean clearly appropriating some Amerindian and Pacific Islander cultural elements without much acknowledgement - but imo the anti-colonialist and environmentalist messages resonate with those same cultures for obvious reasons, that at least for me I can look past the appropriation so long as the film helps people sympathize with the actual evils committed against indigenous peoples, both in the past and today in different forms. It's such a severe shared trauma that real people have to live with - I just hope that like any good art, it inspires people to reflect on their own life and their own world, and maybe notice that so much of western society (particularly the US) is so keen on marginalizing its several thousand years worth of indigenous history.

Anyway, after watching the movie, I went scuba diving. Great stuff man. I highly recommend you find a theater with a projector capable of 4k HFR and 3D if at all possible. (like the IMAX single-laser, or the Barco 4k).

>>179153580
I mean yeah man it's a good movie. Sci Fi is awesome.
I can't speak for the whole tribe, but yeah the feelings can be complicated. And they develop over a lifetime's worth of experiences.

For instance with Dances With Wolves, the whole white savior and noble savage tropes, that kind of sucks. Because neither of those oversimplifications really capture the complexities of two very different cultures and worldviews colliding. And for people who have a personal stake those sorts of cross-cultural interactions, I think it definitely hits close to home. But there's a famous movie line, "The only thing sadder than Indians on TV, is Indians watching Indians on TV." Because we do that, even in the older westerns where we were always the bad guys, we still watch - and the actors were just white guys painted brown. Lol I'll take the noble savage trope any day over being characterized as a beast-like villain. But idk, it's just really cool to see aspects of your own culture in a movie, even if ironically the culture making said movie happens to have evolved out of the same culture that did the colonizing in the first place.

So personally, I don't mind some vaguely inspired indigenous things in the movie, so long as the deeper lessons the film is trying to communicate come across clearly. Because those particular lessons I think are very important ones for this time, place, and culture.

But likewise, I've been curious to hear from some Maoris or other Pacific Islanders how they feel about film featuring a kind of Haka. That's their thing.

Brother Mouzone's character is one of the many anachronisms in The Wire that don't hold up in modern day.
Before 9/11, the Nation of Islam was an actual thing, and deranged, psuedo-intellectual black lunatics like him actually roamed the inner city. Nowadays, not only is the Nation of Islam irrelevant, but somebody like Mouzone would have been van'd by the surveillance state the moment he crossed state lines...if not earlier.

So no, the character didn't make The Wire jump the shark because a) he wouldn't have been seen as anymore ridiculous than the other characters to audiences at the time, and b) everybody knows that McNulty staging the first strangle victim was when The Wire jumped the shark.
